1 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.1 INTRODUCTION
El Paso Water Utilities-Public Service Board (EPWU-PSB) Environmental Services Department performed the five year Risk Management Plan (RMP) update for the Robertson-Umbenhauer Water Treatment Plant.  The Robertson-Umbenhauer Water Treatment Plant is commonly referred to as the Canal WTP.  The Canal WTP is located at 800 Canal Street in El Paso, Texas.  The location is depicted on the Site Location Map in Appendix C.  This plant is adjacent to the international border with Mexico and surrounded by urban, residential and vacant land.

1.2 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
EPWU-PSB has prepared this Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the chlorination process at Canal WTP, in compliance with 40CFR68, found in the EPA's General Risk Management Program Guidance (GRM­ PG), the registration for this process is presented in Appendix A.

The RMP objectives are:
¿	Hazard Assessment-communicate the extent of a possible chlorine release and identify potential receptors
¿	Prevention Program-develop strategies to prevent an accidental release
¿	Emergency Response Program-formulate contingency planning in the case of an accidental release

Hazard Assessment
The worst case scenario modeled by the Areal Locations of Hazardous Atmospheres (ALOHA®) software indicates a vulnerable zone radius of 2.5 miles.  The alternative release analysis indicates a vulnerable zone radius of 13 yards. The Hazard Assessment shows an estimated population within the worst case scenario at 32,200 people; Mexico's potential affected population was unable to be determined however, a comparable population in Mexico resides within the vulnerable zone. The alternative "more likely" release estimated population is approximately 0 people.

The RMP rule requires the identification of environmental receptors within the toxic endpoint zone for both worst case and alternative scenarios. The following environmental receptors were identified:

1.	The R

io Grande River.  The Canal WTP is approximately five-hundred (500) yard from the Rio Grande River. The Rio Grande River is a natural and international border between Mexico and United States and provides habitat for aquatic wildlife. The International Boundary and Water Commission (IBWC), is the responsible agency to monitor the ecosystem of the Rio Grande.

2.	Chamizal National Monument. The Chamizal National Monument is a fifty-nine (59) acre urban park owned by the United States and serves primarily as a cultural center and contains art galleries, a theater and an amphitheater. 

These two environmental receptors qualify as vulnerable zones in the worst case release scenario. There were no vulnerable zones found in the alternative release scenario.

Prevention Program
The goal of the Prevention Program is to integrate technologies, procedures, and management practices to minimize the probability of an accidental chlorine release. The Prevention Program incorporates safety information, hazard review, operating procedures, training, maintenance, compliance audits and incident investigations.

Emergency Response Program
The Emergency Response Program is modeled after the EPWU-PSB's "Emergency Response Action Plan" and the Chlorine Institute Pamphlet 1 Chlorine Basics.  The Emergency Response Program incorporates an emergency response plan, equipment procedures and training in relevant procedures for employees involved in the chlorination process.  

Mexico and The United States created the Jointed Contingency Plan (JCP), designed for rapid international response to contingencies associated with chemical hazardous substances on the inland border. The JCP provides a mechanism for cooperation between the El Paso, Texas, United States of America and Ciudad Juarez, Chihuahua, Mexico. The JCP is designed to protect the health, human safety and the environment by providing international guidance and coordinated responses between the two countries (Mexico-US).

1.3 PLANNED

CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
EPWU-PSB plans to review and revise, as necessary, the chlorination process operating procedures in order to make certain that the operators understand the human factors that may lead to accidental releases.  The emergency response plan is also reviewed and updated to reflect changes and ensure that employees are informed of changes.  

2 HAZARD ASSESSMENT (40CFR68 SUBPART B)

2.1 APPLICIBILITY (§ 68.20)
Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act requires covered facilities to develop Risk Management Programs in an effort to "prevent accidental releases and minimize the consequences of releases." Chlorine (CAS 7782-50-5), a regulated substance under section 112(r)(7) of the Clean Air Act, has a threshold quantity of 2,500 pounds as listed in Table 1 of §68.130. The Canal WTP is subject to the RMP regulation because the chlorination process at the facility utilizes and/or stores a greater quantity of chlorine than the threshold quantity. Currently, the Canal WTP has the potential to store up to twenty-three (23) one-ton chlorine containers in the chlorination storage area, a potential of 46,000 pounds of chlorine.

Under the RMP guidelines, the chlorination process at the Canal WTP qualifies as a Program 2 process. The process is not listed as Program 3 because the facility is not covered under the OSHA Process Safety Management requirements and the process is not part of the SIC codes listed in §68.10(d)(1).  The chlorination process does not qualify for Program 1 status because a worst case release would reach a public receptor, therefore not satisfying §68.10(b)(2).

2.2 OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS PARAMETERS (§ 68.22)

2.1.1 ENDPOINT
As specified in Appendix A for §68.22(a)(1), the toxic endpoint for chlorine is 0.0087 mg/L. The toxic endpoint corresponds to a concentration of 3.0 parts per million (ppm).

2.1.2 WIND SPEED AND ATMOSPHERIC STABILITY CLASS
Per the RMP rule, a wind speed of 1.5 m/s and an F stability class, utilized in the worst

case release analysis. Weak winds, nighttime cooling and little turbulent mixing characterize the F atmospheric stability class.  The atmosphere is considered stable under the F stability classification.  These wind and atmospheric conditions allow for maximum plume transport and are therefore appropriate for a worst case release analysis.

The atmospheric data used for the RMP's update was obtained from the National Weather Service (NWS) Office for the El Paso, Texas region. The NWS station is located at the Dona Ana County Airport at Santa Teresa, New Mexico, approximately 16 miles northwest of downtown El Paso.

For the alternative release scenario, the regulations allow the use of typical meteorological conditions for the geographic area. According to the NWS Office, the average wind speed for El Paso is 8.5 miles per hour (3.8 m/s). The atmospheric conditions would be best described by the C stability classification.  The C classification is representative of a neutral atmosphere with moderate turbulence. These wind and atmospheric conditions are more probable to occur and are therefore used in the alternative "more likely" release scenario.

2.2.3 AMBIENT TEMPERATURE AND HUMIDITY
For the worst-case analysis, the RMP rule requires the use of the highest daily maximum temperature in the previous three years and the average humidity. The three-year (January 2021 through January 2024) maximum temperature for El Paso is 111°F and the daily average relative humidity is 37%.

For the alternative release scenario, the regulations indicate the use of average temperature and humidity data. The average temperature for El Paso is 69.1°F and the daily average relative humidity is 37%.
2.2.4 HEIGHT RELEASE
As indicated in the RMP rule, the worst case scenario analysis assumes a ground level release (0 feet). For the alternative release analysis, the regulation indicates that the release height be determined by the release scenario.  Since the process area is near ground le

vel, the release was assumed to occur at ground level.
2.2.5 SURFACE ROUGHNESS
The software model used in the offsite consequence analysis considers the roughness length (Zo) of the terrain as a parameter in the transport analysis.  For example, Grass (artificial, 7.5 cm high), Grass (thin to 50 cm), Vegetation (1 m to 2 m high) and a Large City (Tokyo) have a roughness length of 1 cm, 5 cm, 20 cm and 165 cm, respectively.  Since the modeling software utilizes a heavy gas model, the software considers a roughness length of up to 10 cm.

The topography of the area near the chlorine process is urban with obstacles in the immediate area such as trees or small buildings. The topography of the area near the chlorine process is desert rangeland with residential housing developments and several industrial areas. A roughness length of 10 cm, the upper limit for the heavy gas model, was selected for both analyses
2.2.6 DENSE OR NEUTRALLY BUOYANT GASES
In accordance with the RMP rule, the dispersion model utilized for the hazard assessment accounted for gas density.  Since chlorine gas is 2.4 times heavier than air, the heavy gas model in Areal Locations of Hazardous Atmospheres (ALOHA®) Version 5.4.7 was utilized for the dispersion analyses, instead of a buoyant gas model.
2.2.7 TEMPERATURE OF RELEASEED SUBSTANCE
For the worst case analysis the RMP rule requires the use of the maximum of either the highest daily maximum temperature in the previous three years or the typical process temperature.  For dispersion modeling purposes, this temperature was 111°F, the highest daily temperature in El Paso, Texas for the previous three years (January 2021 through January 2024).

For the alternative release scenario, the regulations indicate that the substances may be released at process or ambient temperature. For modeling purposes, the chlorine was released at the average ambient temperature of 69.1°F.
2.3 WORST CASE ANALYSIS (§68.25)
The worst case release scenario selected was

the release of the entire contents of a one-ton chlorine container.  According to the EPA's Risk Management Program Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants, the worst case scenario "need only consider the largest vessel, regardless of interconnections with pipes and other vessels."  The worst case analysis performed on the chlorine process indicates a vulnerable zone radius of 2.5 miles (Appendix B) as determined by the ALOHA® modeling software.  The worst case analysis was conducted in compliance with the RMP rule, as presented below.
2.3.1 NUMBER OF RELEASE SCENARIO
For the Program 2 process, the EPWU-PSB analyzed and reported "one worst case release scenario that is estimated to create the greatest distance in any direction to [a toxic endpoint] resulting from an accidental release of regulated toxic substances from covered processes under worst case conditions" (§68.25(2)(i)).
2.3.2 DETERMINATION OF WORST CASE RELEASE QUANTITY
The RMP rule requires "the worst case release quantity shall be the greater of the following: for substances in a vessel, the greatest amount held in a single vessel, taking into account administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity; or for substances in pipes, the greatest amount in pipe taking into account administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity" (§68.25(b)).  The one-ton (2,000-lb) worst case release quantity selected represents the greatest amount held by a single vessel.
2.3.3 WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO FOR TOXIC GASES
According to the RMP rule, "for regulated toxic substances that are normally gases at ambient temperature and handled as a gas or as a liquid under pressure, the owner or operator shall assume that the quantity present  in a vessel ... [will be] released as a gas over 10 minutes.  The release rate shall be assumed to be the total quantity divided by 10, unless passive mitigation systems are in place, then the mitigation factor (i.e. 55 percent) assumes the release occurs in a fully enclos

ed space" (§68.25(c)(1)) and EPA's Release Rates for Toxic Substances:

Calculations:
	2.3.3.1	QR= QS/10 *0.55
	2.3.3.2	QR= 2000/10 * 0.55 = 110
			QR = Release rate (pounds per minute)
			QS = Quantity released (pounds)
			0.55 = Mitigation factor

The chlorine at the Canal WTP is considered a passive-mitigation system since largest the vessels are stored indoors.  The mitigated release rate considered was 110 lb/min (Formula 1).
2.3.4 PARAMETERS TO BE APPLIED
The parameters used to determine the distance to the toxic endpoints is discussed in Section 2.2. The RMP rule states "the owner or operator may use the methodology in the RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance or any commercially or publicly available air dispersion modeling techniques, provided the techniques account for modeling conditions and are recognized by industry as applicable as part of current practices" (§68.25(g)).  The air dispersion model used in the offsite consequence analyses was ALOHA®.  The ALOHA® transport and dispersion modeling software was developed by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).
2.3.5 CONSIDERATION OF PASSIVE MITIGATION
Passive mitigation systems are "equipment, devices or technologies deployed to capture or control hazardous substances upon loss of containment, which function without human, mechanical or other energy input" (§68.3).  Passive mitigation systems were considered for the worst case analysis.  Since the area where the chlorine ton containers are stored is fully enclosed, the partial building enclosure was considered as passive mitigation.
2.4 ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO ANALYSIS (§68.28)
The alternative release scenario selected considered a release rate of 0.002 lb/min over a period of sixty (60) minutes.  The alternative release analysis performed on the chlorine process indicates a vulnerable zone radius of 13 yards (39 feet) (Appendix B). The ALOHA® modeling software determi

ned this radius after the appropriate parameter values were applied.  The alternative release analysis was conducted in compliance with the RMP rules, as presented below.
2.4.1 NUMBERS OF SCENARIOS
The RMP rule requires at least one alternative release scenario be identified and analyzed for each regulated toxic substance held in a covered process (§68.28(a)).  Since chlorine is the only toxic substance used at this facility above, the RMP threshold, one alternative release scenario was identified for the offsite consequence analysis.
2.4.2 SCENARIOS TO CONSIDER
The alternative scenario was defined as a pipe leak between the ton containers and the evaporator based on its likeliness of occurrence.  ALOHA® Source Strength module was used to estimate the release rate.  The alternative release scenario assumed a 1/8 inch diameter hole on a 3/8 inch pipeline. The pipeline was considered as being attached to an infinite source, the release was considered as continuous for a period of 60 minutes.  This is a conservative estimate of the response time by the emergency personnel to an accidental release.
2.4.3 PARAMETERS TO BE APPLIED
The parameters used to determine the distance to the toxic endpoints are discussed in Section 2.2.  ALOHA® was used as the air dispersion model to calculate the distance to toxic endpoints.
2.4.4 CONSIDERATION OF MITIGATION
The Emergency Vapor Scrubber System is considered an active mitigation system.  A mitigation factor for a building enclosure was not used for the alternative release scenario.  The alternative release scenario was based on a hazard review analysis.  The major safety components of the Emergency Vapor Scrubber System include:
¿	Fiberglass Reinforced Plastic Three Stage Scrubber Vessel with Integral Caustic Storage Tank
¿	Air Exhaustion Fan
¿	Recirculation Pump
¿	Local Electrical Control Panel
2.4.5 FACTORS IN SELECTING SCENARIOS
The alternative scenario was defined as a pipe leak between the ton containers and the evapo

rator based on its likeliness of occurrence.  The alternative release scenario description is included in Appendix D.
2.5 DEFINING OFFSITE IMPACTS-POPULATION (§68.30)
2.5.1 POPULATION ESTIMATE
The RMP rule requires an estimate of "the population within a circle with its center at the point of the release and a radius determined by the distance to the [toxic] endpoint" (§68.30(a)).  MARPLOT® Version 5.1.1, a publicly available software program, was utilized to estimate the population based on 2020 U.S. Census data.  This mapping application is used widely to plan for and respond to chemical emergencies. This software was developed by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administrative (NOAA).  

The estimated population within the worst case release radius is approximately 32,200 persons and 13,000 housing units.  Mexico's potential affected population was unable to be determined however, a comparable population in Mexico resides within the vulnerable zone.  The estimated population that resides within the alternative release radius is approximately 0 persons.
2.5.2 POPULATION TO BE DEFINED
Per §68.30(b), the RMP must note "the presence of institutions (schools, hospitals, prisons), parks and recreational areas, and major commercial, office, and industrial, buildings."  The public receptors inside the worst case and alternative release scenario vulnerable zone are listed in Table 2-1 and Table 2- 2, respectively.

2.5.3 DATA SOURCES ACCEPTABLE
The RMP rule requires that the population estimate be based on "the most recent Census data or other updated information" (§68.30(c)).  MARPLOT® uses data from the 2020 U.S. Census and determines the population based on Census Block points located within or touching the circle defined by the radius.  
2.6 DEFINING OFFSITE IMPACTS - ENVIRONMENT (§68.33)
2.6.1 ENVIRONMENTAL RECEPTORS
The RMP rule defines environmental receptors as national or state parks, monuments or forests, officially designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, refuges, or areas and federal wilderness areas.

The RMP rule req

uires the identification of environmental receptors within the toxic endpoint zone for both worst case and alternative scenarios.
1.	The Canal WTP is approximately five-hundred (500) yards from the Rio Grande River.  The Rio Grande provides habitat for aquatic wildlife and is an international border between Mexico and the United States.  The border of El Paso, Texas is in vicinity with Ciudad Juarez, Chihuahua, Mexico.  The International Boundary and Water Commission (IBWC) is the responsible agency to look for healthy ecosystem of the Rio Grande.

2.	Chamizal National Monument. The Chamizal National Monument is a fifty-nine (59) acre urban park owned by the United States and serves primarily as a cultural center and contains art galleries, a theater and an amphitheater.

These habitats qualify as vulnerable zone for environmental receptors in the worst case release scenario. There were not vulnerable zones found in the alternative release scenario.
2.6.2 DATA SOURCES ACCEPTABLE
The RMP rule allows the use of U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) maps or any data source containing USGS data to identify environmental receptors. Environmental receptors were identified using 7.5-minute topographic USGS maps located in Appendix C (Smeltertown and El Paso South).
2.7 REVIEW AND UPDATE (§68.36)
In compliance with the RMP rule, the EPWU-PSB will "update the offsite consequence analyses at least once every five years"(§68.36(a)).  If changes in processes, quantities stored or handled, or any other aspect of the facility might reasonably be expected to increase or decrease the distance to the endpoint by a factor of two or more, the EPWU-PSB will complete a revised analysis  within six months of the change and submit a revised RMP (§68.36(b)).

2.8 DOCUMENTATION (§68.39)
The required records for the offsite consequence analysis are discussed in Sections 2.2 through 2.7.

3 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY (§68.42)
The RMP rule requires the documentation, within the previous five years of

"all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage."  According to Mr. Salvador Morales, Plant Superintendent, accidental chlorine releases have not occurred at this facility in the last five years (January 2019 - January 2024).

4 PROGRAM 2 PREVENTION PROGRAM (§68 SUBPART C)
The objective of this Program 2 Prevention Program is to reduce the risk to EPWU-PSB employees and the public of injury or death from accidental release of chemicals. The requirements for this prevention program are detailed in 40 CFR 68.48 through 68.60.
4.1 MANAGEMENT SYSTEM
The EPWU-PSB has assigned the overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program to Ruben Rodriguez (RMP Program Manager).  Additional individuals have been assigned responsibility for implementing individual requirements and will report to the RMP Program Manager on these matters.  Responsible individuals will communicate information to other employees involved in operation and maintenance of the regulated processes, as required.  All responsible individuals are listed in Appendix E.
4.2 SAFETY INFORMATION (§68.48)
The EPWU-PSB has compiled and maintained up-to-date safety information related to the regulated substances, processes, and equipment at this facility. The contents of this section are summarized in the Safety Information Summary Sheet located in Appendix F.

4.2.1 GENERAL SAFETY INFORMATION
Chlorine is a toxic gas stored as a liquid under pressure.  Chlorine is irritating and corrosive to the eyes, skin, and respiratory tract and reacts violently with easily oxidized materials. Considering that the boiling point for chlorine is -29.4° F, contact with evaporating chlorine or equipment releasing flashing chlorine can cause frostbite burns.  Chlorine gas is heavier than air and wil

l tend to travel along the ground and fill low spaces and pits displacing air.
4.2.1.1 SAFETY DATA SHEETS
A Safety Data Sheet (SDS) for the chlorine process at the facility is included in Appendix G.  Per the RMP rule, the SDS meets the requirements of the OSHA Hazard Communication Standard (HCS) 29 CFR 1910.1200(9).
4.2.1.2 MAXIMUM INTENDED INVENTORY
The maximum intended inventory of chlorine at this facility is 48,000 pounds. This quantity is stored in two areas with a total of twenty-three (24) one-ton chlorine containers. 

Table 4-1: Maximum Intended Inventory
Chemical Name	Maximum Intended Inventory (pounds)
Chlorine	48,000
4.2.1.3 SAFE OPERATING LEVELS
Storage containers are designed for storage at the upper and lower extremes of ambient temperature in normal use and for the pressures that can develop at those temperatures (with additional safety factors).  One-ton containers of chlorine are designed to withstand pressures of at least 330 psig that can develop at a temperature of 165° F, the point at which the fusible plugs melt to relieve pressure in the event of a fire.  Temperatures may drop if chlorine gas is withdrawn to approaching the boiling point of-29.4° F, but are usually higher due to heat transfer from the surrounding air.

Design maximum flows are generally defined by the capacity of the chlorine flow regulating devices. Design minimums are typically zero. The composition will not change until the material is contacted with water, typically in the chlorinators or evaporators.

The upper and lower operating limits may vary from storage containers to point of application depending upon whether the process is feeding vapor or liquid, where a vacuum regulator may be located, and whether the process utilizes an evaporator. The limits must be checked based upon the storage containers and the process design.
4.2.1.4 EQUIPMENT SPECIFICATIONS
Specifications for the equipment utilized in the chlorination process included is in Appendix H.

4.2.2 COMPLIANCE STANDARDS
Per the RMP rule, the EPWU-PSB ensures that the chlorine process at the facility is designed in generally accepted good engineering practices.  The design and operation of the chlorine process adheres to industry-specific design codes and standards set by the Chlorine Institute and/or the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.
4.2.3 UPDATES
If a major change occurs in the chlorine process that makes the safety information inaccurate, the EPWU-PSB will promptly update the information accordingly.  

Items that may be considered major modifications to the chlorine process at this facility include:

¿	Increasing on-site storage capacity of regulated chemicals
¿	Replacing a major equipment item such as a chlorinator with a large capacity model
¿	Increasing piping sizes
¿	Changing disinfection capacity volumes
¿	New building construction

Future major changes that occur at this facility will be documented in Appen

dix I.
4.3 HAZARD REVIEW (§68.50)
4.3.1 CONTENT
4.3.1.1 HAZARDS ASSOCIATED WITH THE PROCESS AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE
Health Hazards:
The predominant hazards associated with the chlorination process are due to the acute toxicity of chlorine gas.  In the event of a chlorine release, the possible health hazards may vary from skin and respiratory irritation to death.  According to the Chlorine lnstitute's Pamphlet 1, Chlorine Basics (8th ed.), "As duration of exposure and/or concentration increases, the affected individual may develop rapid breathing, wheezing and hemoptysis.  In extreme cases difficulty in breathing can progress to the point of death through cardiovascular collapse from respiratory failure."  Permissible and recommended maximum exposure limits for chlorine gas are presented in Table 4-3.

erfere with an individual's ability to escape from a dangerous atmosphere.

Other Hazards:
Chlorine is non-flammable and noncombustible; however, chlorine will support combustion as an oxidizing agent. Chlorine reacts and forms explosive compounds with acetylene, turpentine, ethers, ammonia, hydrocarbons (including oils and grease), hydrogen, and powdered metals.  According to the Chlorine lnstitute's Chlorine Basics (8th ed.), "at ambient temperatures, dry chlorine, either liquid or gas, does not corrode steel." However, chlorine reacts with water to form highly corrosive, acidic solutions (hydrochloric and hypochlorous acids).
4.3.1.2 OPPORTUNITIES FOR EQUIPMENT MALFUNCTIONS OR HUMAN ERRORS
The opportunities for equipment malfunctions or human errors that could cause and accidental release are listed in the What-If Hazard Review Analysis presented in Appendix J.
4.3.1.3 SAFEGUARDS TO CONTROL HAZARDS OR PREVENT EQUIPMENT MALFUNCTION OR HUMAN ERROR
The safeguards used or needed to control the hazards or prevent equipment malfunction or human error are listed in the What-If Hazard Review Analysis presented in Appendix J.
4.3.1.4 DETECTION AND MONITORING OF RELEASES
The ambient air in the chlorination process area is continuously monitored for chlorine gas.  The area monitor is set to alarm at 1.0 ppm.  Additionally, a temperature sensor was added to the chlorine storage room, the system has the ability to recognize temperatures above 115°F, the alarm will activate in a high­ temperature scenario.  The maintenance and calibration of the monitors are performed in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations.
4.3.2 QUALITY ASSURANCE
The EPWU-PSB has determined that the chlorine process was designed, built, and operated in accordance with the applicable codes and industrial guidelines presented in Section 4.2.1.5.
4.3.3 DOCUMENTATION
The EPWU-PSB has documented the results of the hazard review and will ensure that any problems identified will be resolved in a timel

y manner. The Hazard Review Checklist is presented in Appendix K.
4.3.4 UPDATES
The hazard review will be updated at least once every five years.  The EPWU­ PSB will also conduct reviews whenever a major change in the process occurs. Issues identified in the review will be resolved before startup of the changed process occurs.
4.4 OPERATING PROCEDURES (§68.52)
The EPWU-PSB has documented written operating procedures that provide clear instructions or steps for safely conducting activities associated with each covered process consistent with the safety information for that process.

The operating procedures address the following:
¿	Initial startup
¿	Normal operations
¿	Temporary operations
¿	Emergency shutdown and operations
¿	Normal shutdown
¿	Startup following a normal or emergency shutdown or a major change that requires a hazard review
¿	Consequences of deviations and steps required to correct or avoid deviations
¿	Equipment inspections

5.2.2 PURPOSE
The purpose of this Emergency Response Program (ERP) is to effectively respond to a chlorine release to minimize injuries, lessen the impact to the community, minimize plant damage, and provide guidance to local emergency response personnel.
5.2.3 TYPES OF EMERGENCIES
In the event of an equipment or human failure, potential sources for chlorine release are:
1.	One ton chlorine container
2.	Piping, valves, and miscellaneous chlorine process equipment
5.2.4 SCOPE
The scope of this program includes:
1.	A chlorine release contained within the facility and controllable by plant personnel and equipment
2.	A chlorine release affecting, or with potential to affect, the area surrounding the facility, such a release would require outside assistance

This facility is only adequately staffed to respond to chlorine releases during the first shift (7 AM. to 3 P.M.

).  This facility will rely upon outside assistance for chlorine releases that occur during the second shift (3 P.M. to 11 P.M.) and the third shift (11 P.M. to 7 A.M.).
5.2.5 PLANNING AND PROCEDURES FOR AN EMERGENCY 
A review of the Evacuation Plan for EPWU-PSB was conducted for the Canal WTP on October 25, 2018, according to the Public Safety Planner, Hector Padilla. At this time the overall plan seems to be effective and only a few minor adjustments were noted.

The first course of action in a 'worst case scenario' such as a major chlorine leak, would be to alert other employees in the plant using the telephone, radio or intercom system if possible.
The second course of action would be to immediately call 911 to report the type of emergency and location. This should be followed by notifying the EPWU-PSB Dispatch on "Channel 1" as soon as possible for necessary internal actions.
The third course of action should be an evacuation of the plant.  Initially, the designated meeting place to account for all plant personnel will be located outside the South fence by the main gate emergency exit.  If circumstances dictate, such as if wind direction changes, everyone will need to move either East or West along the canal as necessary. If possible, the employee in charge should act as liaison with the Incident Commander from the El Paso Fire Department. This will serve as a contact for information exchange between the two departments.

Fire Station #11 (314 S. Leon) is the closest Fire Station to the Canal WTP.  They would be the first to respond.  In the event of a major accident, HazMat Unit (201 S. Florence Street) would also respond.
Due to the nature of wastewater treatment processes, other types of emergencies remain a possibility.  This plan represents the procedures during a worst case scenario realizing different actions may need to be taken for other emergencies.
5.2.6 EMERGENCY FIRST AID PROCEDURES
Any injured employee suffering from chlorine inhalation should be

sent to the hospital.  To the extent possible, another plant employee should accompany the injured employee.
5.2.6.1 GENERAL
¿	Caution: Use proper PPE to ensure you do not become a casualty
¿	Prompt action is essential; Remove exposed person form contaminated area
¿	Remove contaminated clothing
¿	Wash contaminated body parts with cool, running water Give nothing by mouth if person is unconscious or convulsing
¿	Call a physician as soon as possible
5.2.6.2 GAS INHALATION
If breathing has ceased:
1.	Remove to fresh air and remove and dispose any contaminated clothing
2.	Call for emergency medical assistance
3.	Begin cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) immediately
4.	Trained personnel should administer humidified oxygen by inhalation as soon as possible

If breathing has not ceased:
1.	Move to fresh air and remove and dispose any contaminated clothing
2.	Place patient in a comfortable position
3.	Encourage slow regular breathing
4.	Trained personnel should administer humidified oxygen by inhalation as soon as possible
5.	Keep patient warm and at rest
6.	Render any other necessary first aid
7.	Position patient in chair; in severe cases have the patient lie down with the head and trunk elevated to a 45-60 degree position
5.2.6.3 LIQUID CONTACT
1.	Flush contaminated skin with copious amounts of lukewarm water for at least 15 minutes; remove clothes while in the shower to ensure irrigation of all contaminated skin
2.	Do not attempt chemical neutralization or apply any ointments to damaged skin; apply dressing to protect affected area from contamination or further trauma
3.	Refer to a physician if irritation persists after irrigation or if skin is broken or blistered
4.	If ingested or liquid chlorine has contacted the mouth, flush with copious amounts of lukewarm water for at least 15 minutes and determine presence or absence of burns
5.	If severe burns occur in the mouth then esophageal burns may exist; refer individual to physician or hospital for treatment of ingestion o

f corrosives
5.2.7 ALL CLEAR
The Emergency Response Coordinator is to give the all clear signal when the emergency condition is eliminated.  The notification is to be given verbally to all plant employees, emergency responders, affected neighbors and if involved, the news media.

5.7 INTERNATIONAL AGREEMENTS
5.7.1 BACKGROUND INFORMATION
In order to maintain a good and diplomatic relationship in case of an emergency that might present a threat for Sister Cities, Ciudad Juarez, Chihuahua, Mexico and El Paso, TX, United States of America.  Mexico and The United States created the Joint Contingency Plan (JCP), designed for rapid international response to contingencies associated with chemical hazardous substances in the inland border.   The JCP provides a mechanism for cooperation between the Sister Cities.  The Inland Border plan is not designed to overrule any statutory authorities held by either participant nor misconceive legally binding rights or obligation of the international and domestic laws.
5.7.2 PURPOSE
The purpose of the JCP is based on La Paz Agreement, signed on August 14, 1983. The JCP is designed to effectively respond to significant chemical hazardous contingencies, chlorine in this scenario.  It also aims to protect the health, human safety, and the environment by providing international guidance, joint, and coordinated responses between sister cities (Mexico-US).
5.7.3 PLANNING AND PROCEDURES FOR AN EMERGENCY
After EPWU-PSB have implemented its Emergency Evacuation Plan, Mexico/U.S. Co-chairs coordinating authorities must be notified of the major chlorine leak.
